taskTitle: Determine Appropriate Project Methodology/Methods and Practices

quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Different mountains need different climbing strategies‚Äîpick the right method!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: You're planning expeditions to three different mountains: (1) Mount Kilimanjaro‚Äîstraightforward route, clear weather forecasts, predictable challenges. (2) Mount Everest‚Äîextreme weather, high altitude sickness risk, complex logistics, frequent changes. (3) A technical rock climbing peak‚Äîspecific techniques required, small team, high precision needed. Your sponsor wants one standard climbing method for all three.
quickScenarioChallenge.question: Should you use the same methodology for all three mountains?

options.B: No‚Äîeach mountain requires different methodology tailored to its constraints and risks
options.C: Use Agile for unpredictable mountains (Everest), Waterfall for predictable (Kilimanjaro)
options.D: Ask the sponsor what they prefer

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: B - Tailor methodology to project characteristics

insights.explanation: Different projects have different constraints, risks, and unknowns. Predictable projects suit Waterfall/plan-driven. Uncertain projects suit Agile/iterative. Complex technical projects need hybrid approaches.
insights.pmbokSupport: Project managers tailor processes, methodologies, and practices to fit project context

insights.explanation: Tailoring involves selecting and adapting practices from frameworks like Agile, Waterfall, Lean, Six Sigma, etc. It's not one-size-fits-all.
insights.pmbokSupport: PMBOK Principle: 'Select and tailor the project management approach'

trapSection.explanation: Religious adherence to a single methodology ignores project reality. Some projects need structure; others need flexibility. Great managers adapt.

trapTable.violation: Kilimanjaro doesn't need daily sprints. Everest needs more flexibility than Waterfall allows.
Sponsor doesn't understand methodology‚Äîthat's the PM's expertise to provide

checklist: How predictable is the project scope?
How much uncertainty in requirements or environment?
What's the pace of change expected?
patternRecognition.patternRule: Predictable + stable requirements ‚Üí Plan-driven (Waterfall). Uncertain + changing requirements ‚Üí Agile/iterative. Mixed ‚Üí Hybrid. Always tailor.

coreFramework.frameworkIntro: Choosing the right methodology requires matching project characteristics to approach:

rows.action: Assess: Scope clarity, requirements stability, team experience, regulatory constraints, stakeholder availability, pace of change, organizational culture.
Rate predictability on spectrum: High (Waterfall candidate) vs Low (Agile candidate). Consider both scope and environment predictability.
keyQuestions: Can we define all requirements upfront?

rows.action: Consider framework options: Traditional (Waterfall), Agile (Scrum, Kanban), Lean, Six Sigma, Hybrid (Scrumfall), or tailored blend. Match to context.
Consider org culture, team skills, and stakeholder readiness. Agile requires different mindset than Waterfall. Don't force a method teams aren't ready for.
rows.examKeywords: Organizational readiness, Team capability, Change management

rows.action: Tailor selected framework: Which practices to use? Which to skip? What cadence (2-week sprints, phase gates, continuous flow)? What artifacts and ceremonies?
Document the methodology decision: Why this approach? Which practices? How will it be executed? Share with team and stakeholders.

pmbokConnection.principle: Principle 1: Select and Tailor the Project Management Approach
pmbokConnection.quote: Project managers select and tailor the approach, processes, and practices to meet the specific needs and constraints of the project

visualReferenceCard.quickReference: **Waterfall** for predictable scope, clear requirements upfront | **Agile** for uncertain scope, changing requirements, fast feedback | **Hybrid** for mixed predictability
visualReferenceCard.goldenRule: The best methodology is the one that fits YOUR project, YOUR team, and YOUR organization‚Äînot the one that's trendy.
visualReferenceCard.examTip: Look for 'methodology,' 'approach,' 'Agile vs Waterfall' ‚Üí First action: ASSESS PROJECT CONTEXT before jumping to a framework.
visualReferenceCard.pmbokPrinciple: Tailoring - Match methodology to project characteristics

secondScenario.title: Apply T.A.I.L.O.R.
secondScenario.scenarioStory: Your organization is launching three projects: (1) Building an internal payroll system with fixed scope and regulatory requirements; (2) Developing a new mobile app for unknown market demands; (3) Upgrading infrastructure with some unknowns but mostly predictable tasks. Your sponsor says 'We're an Agile organization now‚Äîuse Agile for everything.'
secondScenario.question: How would you tailor methodology for each project?

options.A: Use Agile for all three‚Äîorganizational standard
options.B: Payroll = plan-driven (fixed scope, regulatory). Mobile = Agile (uncertain). Infrastructure = Hybrid. Tailor to fit context.
options.C: Let each project manager choose their own approach
options.D: Use Waterfall for all three‚Äîmore predictable

quotes.text: Agile isn't always better than Waterfall‚Äîand Waterfall isn't always wrong. The best methodology is the one that matches your project's constraints and your team's capability.
quotes.author: Andrew Ramdayal

quotes.text: There is no single right approach for all projects. Project managers must select and tailor the methodology to fit the specific project context.
quotes.author: PMI

fieldInsights.title: Methodology is a Tool, Not a Religion
fieldInsights.insight: Too many organizations force every project into their preferred framework regardless of fit. The smartest teams assess context, select the right tools, and adapt as needed.

personalApplication.title: Reflect on Your Project Methodology

questions.question: What methodology does your project currently use?
How well does it fit your project's characteristics?

personalApplication.valueStatement: The right methodology for your project is a competitive advantage.

memoryPalace.title: Memory Palace: The Mountain Selection Lodge

story.title: Choosing the Climbing Strategy
story.narrative: At the lodge before each expedition, the lead guide must choose the right climbing strategy for that specific mountain...

scenes.description: Kilimanjaro: clear route, stable weather, known hazards. Everest: extreme weather, altitude sickness, frequently changing conditions. Rock peak: technical skills required, small team.
Kilimanjaro = highly predictable (route, timeline, hazards known). Everest = low predictability (weather windows change daily). Rock = medium (techniques known, execution varies).
Traditional step-by-step approach (Kilimanjaro), flexible daily adaptation (Everest), technical precision + team improvisation (Rock peak). Each needs different strategy.
Team trained for Kilimanjaro method? Ready for Everest's flexibility? Have rock climbing experience? Don't use extreme mountain tactics on easy peak‚Äîwaste of effort.
Kilimanjaro: Step-by-step daily schedule, fixed camps, planned meals. Everest: Flexible departure times, weather windows, daily pivots. Rock: Pre-planned routes with in-situ adjustments.
Write strategy document: 'Everest uses daily adaptation model because weather unpredictable. Kilimanjaro uses fixed schedule because conditions stable.' Team briefed and agrees.

story.moral: Guide **T**racks characteristics, **A**ssesses predictability, **I**dentifies options, **L**everages readiness, **O**ptimizes tailoring, **R**ecords the plan for each mountain.
